A devotee tolerates all difficulties or dangers or any harm by thinking that due to my own past sinful activities in the past, my own past sinful activities, I deserve to suffer much more.

But by Krishna's grace, I am getting a very small token of punishment. So let me just suffer. Let me not forget Krishna, even in the midst of difficulty or danger. And let me never forget Krishna, even if I am going through some happiness or going through some period where I have lot of benefits or lot of good things coming my way.
In either case, I don't want to forget Krishna. My destination is to go back to Godhead. And I simply have to be Krishna conscious. That's all under all circumstances.

Therefore, Maharaj Pariksit could understand that the bull was no other than the personality of religion himself. In other words, a devotee has no suffering at all because so called suffering is God's grace for a devotee who sees God in everything.
The cow and bull never die.

The cow and bull never placed any complaint before the king for being tortured by the personality of Kali, although everyone lodges such complaints before the state authorities. The extraordinary behavior of the bull made the king conclude that the bull was certainly the personality of religion, for no one else could understand the finer intricacies of the codes of religion.
So therefore, the conclusion is that there are mudras.

There are multiple causes and a devotee depends upon Krishna under all circumstances and by Krishna's grace, the devotee is able to go through all situations in Krishna consciousness and ultimately go back to Godhead, irrespective of whether there was suffering in the course of living life in this body or there was some enjoyment or there was some peace or there was some chaos.
Whatever be the situation, devotees simply are Krishna conscious and they go back to Godhead at the end of life.
I'll stop here. Thank you very much. Hare Krishna.
